data: Lamina. Broken into twelve heavily damaged and burnt fragments, of which 4 are the most complete and legible.
Fragment 1 is not contiguous with fragment 5, which consists of three contiguous fragments and is the upper right corner of the recto of one lamina.
The text is boustrophedon and runs on both face a and face b of the lamina. Two of the larger fragments are included here. Text fragment 5 is the upper right-hand end of the lamina.

Found in Monte San Mauro (di Caltagirone), at the top of Hill 3 (in Orsi's 1910 numbering), 30 cm below the ground level, 
                            in the area where the building in square blocks that Orsi interpreted as an 'anaktoron' was found. The fragments would have penetrated the rammed earth, which was the original walking surface of the structure..
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.
Iscrizioni greche arcaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. III. Iscrizioni delle colonie euboiche
Renato Arena, Iscrizioni greche arcaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. III. Iscrizioni delle colonie euboiche, vol. 3 (Pisa: Nistri Lischi, 1994)
Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l'étude du vocabulaire grec colonial
Laurent Dubois, Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l’étude du vocabulaire grec colonial, CEFR 119 (Rome: Ecole française de Rome, 1989)
Le leggi calcidesi di Monte San Mauro di Caltagirone

Federica Cordano, Roberto Missoni, e Umberto Spigo, «Le leggi calcidesi di Monte San Mauro di Caltagirone», in Decima Miscellanea greca e romana, Studi pubblicati dall’Istituto italiano per la storia antica 36 (Roma, 1986), 33–60
Margherita Guarducci, Epigrafia greca, 4 voll. (Rome: Istituto Poligrafico dello Stato, Libreria dello Stato, 1967)
The local scripts of archaic Greece
L.H. Jeffery and A.W. Johnston, The Local Scripts of Archaic Greece, 2nd edn (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1990)
The Local Scripts of Archaic Greece

L.H. Jeffery, ‘Anne Jeffery Archive’ (CSAD Oxford, n.d.), J.WC.L.R, Anne Jeffery Archive
Inscriptiones graecae Siciliae et infimae Italiae ad ius pertinentes
V. Arangio Ruiz and A. Olivieri, Inscriptiones graecae Siciliae et infimae Italiae ad ius pertinentes (Milan, 1925)
Di una anonima città siculo-greca a Monte S. Mauro presso Caltagirone
Paolo Orsi, «Di una anonima città siculo-greca a Monte S. Mauro presso Caltagirone», Monumenti Antichi 20 (1910): 730–850
Sui frammenti bronzei iscritti da Monte san Mauro
Pier Giovanni Guzzo, «Sui frammenti bronzei iscritti da Monte san Mauro», Atti e Memorie della Società Magna Grecia 5, fasc. 4 (2019): 187–93

Italy Sicily Siracusa Museo Archeologico Regionale Paolo Orsi 30839 Ancient Greek

Lamina. Broken into twelve heavily damaged and burnt fragments, of which 4 are the most complete and legible.

bronze lamina 0.2 Fragment 1 is not contiguous with fragment 5, which consists of three contiguous fragments and is the upper right corner of the recto of one lamina. engraved

The text is boustrophedon and runs on both face a and face b of the lamina. Two of the larger fragments are included here. Text fragment 5 is the upper right-hand end of the lamina.

 Line 1 7-10 Monte San Mauro (di Caltagirone) 37.21765, 14.46907 6th century BCE (so Dubois on letters). Found in Monte San Mauro (di Caltagirone), at the top of Hill 3 (in Orsi's 1910 numbering), 30 cm below the ground level, in the area where the building in square blocks that Orsi interpreted as an 'anaktoron' was found. The fragments would have penetrated the rammed earth, which was the original walking surface of the structure.37.21765, 14.46907. Mignosa 2022-01-17
